content.definition: Parkinson Disease is a progressive neurodegenerative movement disorder caused by the selective loss of [[63593303|dopaminergic neurons]] in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), characterized by the accumulation of intracellular eosinophilic inclusions known as Lewy bodies (composed of $\alpha$-synuclein).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Depletion of dopamine in the [[c30e26a4|nigrostriatal pathway]] leads to disinhibition of the indirect pathway and inhibition of the direct pathway within the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], resulting in net motor inhibition.
  • Clinical Presentation: The classic TRAP tetrad: Tremor (pill-rolling at rest), Rigidity (cogwheel), Akinesia/bradykinesia (shuffling gait, masked facies), and Postural instability.
  • Histology: Loss of pigmented neurons in the SNc and presence of Lewy bodies.
  • Treatment: Increase dopamine availability (e.g., [[335b4671|Levodopa/carbidopa]]), inhibit breakdown (e.g., [[227f8980|Selegiline]]), or stimulate receptors directly (e.g., [[c36650bd|dopamine agonists]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]] by the timeline: in PD, motor symptoms precede cognitive decline by >1 year; in LBD, dementia occurs within 1 year of motor onset.
content.takeAway: The fundamental deficit in Parkinson Disease is the loss of dopaminergic input to the [[644fc3b4|striatum]], which normally facilitates movement via D1 receptors (direct pathway) and suppresses inhibition via D2 receptors (indirect pathway); the resulting imbalance creates a hypokinetic or "frozen" motor state.

content.definition: The Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc) is a specific population of pigmented, dopaminergic neurons located in the midbrain tegmentum that serves as the primary source of [[90adc821|dopamine]] for the [[3fa071ef|caudate]] and putamen (striatum), modulating the direct and indirect pathways of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Synthesizes dopamine from tyrosine to modulate voluntary movement intensity and coordination via the [[c30e26a4|nigrostriatal pathway]].
  • Location: Midbrain, appearing as a dark band ("substantia nigra" = black substance) due to neuromelanin accumulation as a byproduct of dopamine synthesis.
  • Pathology: Selective degeneration occurs in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: Gross examination of a brain with advanced Parkinson's reveals distinct depigmentation (pallor) of the substantia nigra compared to a healthy brain.
content.takeAway: The SNc acts as the "volume dial" for movement; without its dopaminergic output, the basal ganglia defaults to a state of excessive inhibition of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], preventing motor initiation.

content.definition: Multiple Sclerosis is an autoimmune inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system mediated by autoreactive T-cells and macrophages targeting [[a24f9747|oligodendrocytes]], resulting in multiple white matter lesions separated by space (anatomy) and time.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Th1 and Th17 cells cross the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]], recognize myelin antigens, and recruit macrophages, leading to plaque formation and axonal transection.
  • Clinical Presentation: Relapsing-remitting symptoms including [[98a63a59|optic neuritis]] (painful visual loss), [[58c684bd|internuclear ophthalmoplegia]] (INO), scanning speech, intention tremor, and bladder dysfunction.
  • Diagnosis: MRI showing [[d9286430|periventricular plaques]] (Dawson fingers); CSF showing oligoclonal bands (IgG) and elevated myelin basic protein.
  • Treatment: Acute flares managed with IV [[adc34ee4|steroids]]; disease-modifying therapies include [[00e48ea3|$\beta$-interferon]], [[88fffc48|glatiramer]], and [[ae20a0ce|natalizumab]].
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a young female patient with visual changes and an MLF lesion (bilateral INO) is pathognomonic for MS; unilateral INO is often vascular (stroke).
content.takeAway: Multiple Sclerosis is defined by the spatial and temporal dissemination of lesions; identifying two distinct neurological deficits occurring at different times (e.g., optic neuritis followed by paresthesias months later) is key to the clinical diagnosis.

content.definition: Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a specific conjugate horizontal gaze palsy caused by a lesion in the [[59ad6172|medial longitudinal fasciculus]] (MLF), characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye during lateral gaze.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Disruption of the highly myelinated pathway connecting the [[01c1b782|CN VI]] nucleus (pons) to the contralateral [[68c66997|CN III]] nucleus (midbrain).
  • Clinical Sign: When looking LEFT, the RIGHT eye cannot adduct (stuck at midline), and the LEFT eye exhibits nystagmus. Convergence is typically preserved.
  • Etiology: Bilateral lesions are classic for [[45dd6d19|Multiple sclerosis]] in young patients; unilateral lesions suggest lacunar stroke in elderly patients.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic "INO = Ipsilateral adduction failure, Nystagmus Opposite." The side of the INO is the side of the adduction deficit (MLF lesion side).
content.takeAway: The hallmark of INO is the dissociation between horizontal gaze (impaired adduction) and convergence (preserved adduction), proving the lesion is in the interconnecting tract (MLF) rather than the medial rectus muscle or oculomotor nerve itself.

content.definition: The Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF) is a heavily myelinated white matter tract located near the midline of the brainstem that integrates inputs from the oculomotor, trochlear, abducens, and vestibular nuclei to coordinate conjugate eye movements and vestibulo-ocular reflexes.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Transmits excitatory signals from the [[01c1b782|abducens nucleus]] (CN VI) to the contralateral [[68c66997|oculomotor nucleus]] (CN III) medial rectus subnucleus to allow coordinated horizontal gaze.
  • Location: Dorsal pons and midbrain, ventral to the fourth ventricle/cerebral aqueduct.
  • Vulnerability: Highly susceptible to demyelination in [[45dd6d19|Multiple sclerosis]] due to high myelin content required for rapid signal transmission.
  • USMLE Tip: Think of the MLF as the "sync cable" that allows you to look to the side with both eyes simultaneously.
content.takeAway: Speed is essential for binocular vision to prevent diplopia during rapid eye movements; the MLF's heavy myelination facilitates this speed but makes it a prime target in demyelinating diseases like MS, leading to [[58c684bd|INO]].

content.definition: Glaucoma is a group of optic neuropathies characterized by progressive structural damage to the [[0fee2f38|optic nerve]] and retinal ganglion cells, usually (but not always) associated with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP), leading to peripheral vision loss.
content.atAGlance:
• Types: Open-angle (painless, gradual, trabecular meshwork dysfunction) vs. Closed-angle (painful, acute emergency, pupillary block).
  • Pathophysiology: Imbalance between [[d595b0bf|aqueous humor]] production (ciliary body) and outflow (trabecular meshwork/uveoscleral pathway).
  • Fundoscopy: Pathologic cupping of the optic disc (cup-to-disc ratio > 0.5).
  • Treatment: Decrease production ([[10535992|$\beta$-blockers]], [[bc6647e5|$\alpha$-agonists]], [[1df262e8|carbonic anhydrase inhibitors]]) or increase outflow ([[73ad9529|prostaglandins]], [[36054a34|cholinomimetics]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma presents as a painful red eye, rock-hard to palpation, with a fixed mid-dilated pupilâ€”do not give epinephrine (mydriasis worsens the angle).
content.takeAway: Vision loss in Glaucoma is typically peripheral ("tunnel vision") and irreversible because the increased pressure compresses the optic nerve vasculature and axons at the lamina cribrosa, inducing apoptosis.
